intro: Paraspalathus leucocephala, commonly known as the white-headed spurge, is a flowering plant native to parts of Africa. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its milky sap, which can be toxic. The plant typically grows in dry, arid environments and has small, yellowish-green leaves. Its flowers are inconspicuous, with a unique structure that includes a cyathium, a cup-like arrangement of modified leaves and flowers. Paraspalathus leucocephala is often found in rocky soils and is adapted to withstand harsh environmental conditions.
